title-group.article-title: Single-Cylinder Engine Facility to Study Cold Starting - Results with Propane and Gasoline

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright 1993 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.

abstract.p: A unique, temperature controlled, single-cylinder engine test facility was designed and constructed to simulate cold starting of a car engine. The temperature of the coolant, oil, fuel and air used by the engine can be individually controlled to -29Â°C. Moreover, the engine is enclosed in a temperature controlled insulated chamber. With this facility the conditions that occur in a car engine as it cranks and starts, can be quickly duplicated and maintained for detailed study. The supply equivalence ratio values for starting the engine were determined using either gasoline with port fuel injection or propane as a premixed charge. For gaseous propane, the supply equivalence ratio for starting was nearly constant at air temperatures studied. However, for gasoline the supply equivalence ratio for starting increased as the temperature was lowered. The significance of these findings is discussed.

ref.mixed-citation: N. Ostrouchov, "Effects of Cold Weather on Motor Vehicle Emissions and Fuel Economy," SAE Paper 780084, 1978.
J. C. Polak, "Cold Ambient Temperature Effects on Emissions from Light-Duty Motor Vehicles," SAE Paper 741051, 1974.
R. W. Johnston, J. J. Newman, and P. D. Agarwal, "Programmable Energy Ignition System for Engine Optimization," Paper 750348, SAE Transactions, Vol. 84, 1975.
A. A. Quader, "What Limits Lean Operation in Spark Ignition Engines -Flame Initiation or Propagation?" Paper 760760, SAE Transactions, Vol. 85, 1976.
A. A. Quader, "How Injector, Engine, and Fuel Variables Impact Smoke and Hydrocarbon Emissions with Port Fuel Injection," Paper 890623, SAE Transactions, Vol. 98, 1989.
C.J. Dasch, N. D. Brinkman, and D. H. Hopper, "Cold Starts Using M-85 (85% Methanol): Coping with Low Fuel Volatility and Spark Plug Wetting," SAE Paper 910865, 1991.
